awd_titl_txt: RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT, GLOBAL VALUE CHAINS, AND GLOBALIZATION MEASUREMENT: A WORKSHOP
awd_abstract_narration:
In recent decades, production processes of final products have been increasingly fragmented across countries in what is called global value chains (GVCs). Production of intermediate goods or services is increasingly outsourced to a foreign affiliate, in the case of multinational companies, or to unrelated companies. Estimates are that about 70 percent of all global trade is in these intermediate goods and services. This increased use of global value chains poses challenges for our statistical system. While National Statistical Organizations collect a great deal of information on economic performance, trade, employment, and foreign direct investment, this information cannot always be used to quantify the international linkages and flows that characterize these cross-border transactions, especially those related to research and development (R&D) or software. The project will convene a 2-day workshop in which a diverse group of experts will address issues concerning the measurement of R&D in the context of GVCs. The long-term objective of the workshop is to help improve the quality of published statistics relevant to R&D and GVCs, and thereby advance understanding of the impacts of GVCs on employment, innovation, global competitiveness, and other economic issues. More accurate and complete characterization of economic activity and economic health will improve governments' capabilities for assessing current and prospective economic policies, the nature of R&D in GVCs and the overall role companies play in it, and any national security implications of the current or prospective landscape. 

Workshop participants will include experts from the U.S. and abroad in fields such as industrial organization, international trade, and the accounting/taxation of multinational enterprises, as well as staff from (U.S. and foreign) national statistical offices. Original research will be commissioned in advance of the workshop. The workshop will include short panel discussions of the commissioned papers followed by interactive sessions facilitated by key stakeholders. Workshop sessions will guide participants to integrate theoretical and disciplinary perspectives on R&D and GVCs, highlight gaps and inconsistencies in the current measurement of R&D in GVCs, evaluate ongoing efforts to address these gaps, examine national and international manuals used to provide statistical guidance on measurements of R&D and globalization, and identify and prioritize potential improvements in data collection and analysis, among other topics. Workshop outputs will include: (i) the set of research papers solicited in advance of the meeting; and (ii) a Proceedings of the presentations and discussions that summarizes key issues raised during the meeting, including possible strategies for collaboration among U.S. statistical agencies regarding measurement of global R&D and avenues for international collaboration to update statistical manuals related to globalization and R&D.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine held a three-day international workshop via Zoom webinar to address measurement needs and related gaps in the theory on globalization of research and development and published a proceedings volume summarizing the workshop discussions. Understanding the nature of research and development within global value chains is important for determining their impact on trade flows, employment, and growth, and effective data collection is needed to inform our understanding of the effectiveness of current policies and to consider the potential impacts of policies under consideration.

The National Academies workshop, held on 5-7 May 2021, featured a series of papers selected by a nine-member expert planning committee, with additional insights provided by discussants, followed by additional panels focused on measurement issues and reflections on key workshop takeaways. The planning committee received 62 abstracts for proposed papers, and there were over 370 people who pre-registered for the workshop, from a variety of countries and organizations, in addition to the speakers and committee members.

Insights from the workshop could contribute to better and internationally comparable measures of R&D globalization in surveys by NCSES and its Federal agency partners in support of productivity growth and competitiveness, R&D and innovation policy, and enhanced treatment of intangibles in national accounts. The event outcomes may also inform future research and data development. Cross-disciplinary collaboration, including data science and 'open data' approaches, is warranted given the inter-disciplinary nature of economic globalization. The published workshop proceedings can suggest opportunities for U.S. statistical agencies to collaborate on measures of R&D globalization consistent with recent updates in data policy, as well as potential international collaboration to implement any updated or new statistical manuals related to globalization and R&D.

Improving the collection of data related to global value chains and our understanding of it could reduce inaccuracies in trade deficit estimates, allow for more accurate mapping of geographic clustering of economic activity, and permit better understanding of the effect changes in U.S. exports and imports may have on employment in particular industries and domestic regions along with the international competitiveness of various U.S. industries. It can also better inform the allocation of government funding for R&D and assist in mapping global value creation. Improved data also should improve the description and analysis of supply-chain management practices, thus deepening understanding of management's impact on productivity and innovation, as well as the vibrancy of supplier ecosystems.

General information about the workshop, including the agenda, presentations, and papers and a link to the published proceedings, which is available for free download, are available on the National Academies Board on Science, Technology, and Economic Policy website https://www.nationalacademies.org/our-work/understanding-the-impact-of-global-value-chains-a-workshop.
